text:
Definitely the touchscreen. How can it be illegal to text on your phone, but not use one of those things? The whole point of them is you have to look at them to use them, so you're not looking at the road.

The other is the way manufacturers are making it harder to fix even the simplest thing. On my car, the headlight bulb goes, I take the back off the headlight and replace the bulb. text: I love the electronic handbrake on my new BMW. If you like you can just push the button to activate it but you don't even need to do that. With Brake Hold activated (the thing that lets you take your foot off the brake and holds the car in place while idling) all you need to do is switch off the car and step out. author: Greg B

text:
You would think that the bongs would be annoying yet some people still manage to ignore them.  Example?  On my car, if the turn indicator is not turned off within....I am guessing 60 seconds, the annoying ticking sound becomes a loud bong.  How do I know this? There was a car behind me a few months ago that signalled a turn for MILES, so when I tried to alert the driver to the annoyance, I discovered this "feature".
Conversely, because the dome light on my car does not work (my car is a retired police car), it has been nice to know, via a beeping sound, that one of the doors is not completely closed.

I hate electronic emergency brakes because unlike a conventional lever or foot brake, you can't always tell by looking at the button if the emergency brake is on or off.
And the proliferation of different shifting....handles? knobs? buttons? is stupidity bordering on dangerous.  In the 50s the US government stepped in because manufacturers had different automatic transmission shift arrangements.  Some had PRNDL, while some had PDRNL, and others had other arrangements.  You shouldn't have to consult your owner's manual to find out how to shift an automatic transmission equipped vehicle.

Finally, spare tires weren't just deleted to save space, but also to save WEIGHT.  As I understand it, the brackets/classes for allowable emissions from your car's tailpipe are broken up into myriad groups separated in some cases by 50 pounds.  A spare steel wheel WITHOUT a  tire for a compact car can weigh 20 pounds....add a tire and the total for a compact car jumps to nearly 30 pounds, or more than half of that 50 pounds.  And my experience from traveling several thousands of miles per year?  Folks rarely get flats, and when they do they don't want to get dirty and sweaty changing a tire....assuming they even have enough confidence to tackle the job.  IOW, they call roadside assistance.Ôªø

3. Start stop technology is pretty good, on my Skoda Kodiaq, I save 10% of my fuel with this feature and on my Volkswagen Tiguan r-line tdi, it cuts out the desire noise when at idle so this feature is pretty good and it doesn‚Äôt actually affect any other features
4. Electronic hand break, on my Skoda Octavia RS, it takes up more room than it does in my Tiguan or Skoda kodiaq, with the electronic hand break and auto hold, it makes it so much more conventional. 
5. Infotainment screen... in my Skodas and Volkswagen‚Äôs, u can either do the stuff through the drivers instrument  cluster (digital cockpit) or do it using the physical buttons or the media system 
So I can basically disagree with everything in this videoÔªø

author: DANX

text:
All electric windows. Seems great but especially in the back they're a ballache. Kids don't stop cocking around with them, then they complain it's too hot/cold when you lock them.

 Inbuilt sat nav. Just, no. They're clunky and unreliable most of the time, are often part of the radio/CD player (if new cars still have those) and at least on Peugeots, they turn on by themselves even if you turned the screen off (it turns off properly when reversing (sensible idea) but then when you put it in neutral or 1st it comes on full glare, like WTF, I turned it off for a reason)

Bluetooth. Kids these days are tech savvy. They'll connect before I do. Those little shits will then play their shit on a loop for the next 20000000 miles and I can't do anything to stop them because Johnny copper will have me for using my phone or the kids will cry because it's not the Frozen soundtrack.

The Ford flippy badge thing to open the bonnet. First off, it means taking the key out the ignition, not ideal if I'm trying to check what's making that squeaky noise. Second, some sticky fingered little arsehole will play around with it, break it then get something stuck in the keyhole leaving me unable to refill the radiator YOU BROKE THE CAR TIMMY!!! DON'T CRY BECAUSE YOU MISSED LEGOLAND, YOU STOPPED DADDY FROM FILLING THE BLOODY RADIATOR, YOU SNOT-FACED WANKER!!!

Those extra stalks for the Radio controls. I want to indicate left, not skip past Dancing Queen, that shit is my racing music.

Horns on the steering wheel. Just bring back the little trumpet thing with the rubber squeezy bit. Those things take the edge off road rage.

Oddly positioned signals. Often this encompasses the side indicator, one expects this below the mirror, just ahead of the door. Quirky ones on a mirror tip or some other bizarre place take longer to spot and make the car look stupid.

STDIGTRVTECRSXYZ etc bollocks. I swear by this point everything has some assortment of "performance" lettering on the back. I don't give a shit if it's got RS TDI STD TURBOMEGA BOOSTER on the back. It's still a Polo and it detracts from true performance packages. 

(Applies to one particular brand) BMW logos plastered everywhere. The indicators even have them. Beemers are cool but sticking the logo on every surface just looks pretentious.

"Super-mini" in the description. It's a fucking landbarge. The Fiat 500 and Mini Cooper (BMW) are the worst culprits. The originals were compact enough to drive on the pavement and still leave room for the postman. Now they're the same size as everything else.

The Chelsea Tractor. We're talking Range Rover Sport+Vogue, Porsche Cayenne, Audi Q series, BMW X series and tragically even the Disco 4. A 4x4 is for having fun on a muddy mountain, not for lugging kids around in while taking up an entire road with terrible parking.

On that subject, treadplate on brand new Defenders (RIP). It started out as a farmers on the spot repair. You're a drug dealer in Brighton, Carl, you look like a twat.

Garish colours. In the good old days you had Tasteful Blue, Handsome Black, Civilised Green and Charming red. Now you see things in such a bright shade of orange your face melts up and the dog throws up in shock. Also, why would anyone want a car in the same shade of brown as a lump of dog shit?

Pockets on the backs of seats. Trying to spruce the car up, make it look nice when I take granny to the airp... FUCK SAKE TIMMY!! WHY IS THERE HAF A FUCKING LOLLIPOP STUCK IN HERE!? JESUS FUCK NO!! DON'T EAT IT!!!!Ôªø

text:
1. Small turbocharged engines instead of bigger n/a engines
2. sporty luxury cars. These are opposites don't try to make them work. it's like an economical SUV it never really works!
3. keyless start. Although I don't mind the feature, it does come with an annoying side affect. WHERE DO I PUT MY KEY NOW?!
4. No decent space to put my phone. If I want to use it as navigation I have to put it somewhere far down which isn't really save or it just slides about
5. Making maintenance impossible to work on. Why can't I even change my oil anymore without a computer and non re-usable clips.
6. all the driving modes. I don't need a sport, sport+, sport++, race, race+, track and hardcore driving mode in the same car! Because we all know we only use the most extreme versions. Nobody has ever driven a car and thought: hm, I wan't my car to drive a little bit more sporty then comfort but sport++ is a bit to much. Just  leave it at 3 different modes MAX!
7. Fewer and fewer cars with an optional manual. Or only available with the smallest engine. If you want a manual transmission, you are almost certain a sporty driver so why on the smallest engines only? More manuals and preferably on the big engines!
8. upshift "advice" light! I will decide when I change up. You don't have to tell me that! If I want to hear money exploding I will!

There a new video idea for ya. feel free to use it, just mention that you got the idea from a Dutch bloke.Ôªø

text: I don't want to rely on electronics to do crucial things. If my power windows fail, fuck it, I can deal with not rolling down the windows for a bit. If my power steering fails, I can drive without that. If my fucking handbrake fails, I can't deal with that. I trust mechanical parts that are time tested and reliable. Give me something that has been around almost as long as cars have been, and that has been perfected, over something that is finicky and unproven. Cars are dangerous, and I don't want them to become unnecessarily more dangerousÔªø

author: Saad Khan

text: I bought a base Model 2018 BMW X1 sDrive28i implicitly because I didn't want all those extra bells and whistles that were surely to screw up at some point.  I don't need a panoramic sunroof taking up all the roof space.  I don't care if I can put my hand in the handle and have it automatically open.  I can easily hit the button on my key faub.  I dont need a bunch of "safety features" because I'm a professional truck driver of 12 years and I know to drive safely.  I'm not saying all extra features are bad.  Backup cameras are a good thing.  I love dual zone climate control.  Love the remote hatch opener on my faub.  My iDrive is cool.  However, simplicity is often the better direction to go towards.  My SAV came with the three options I would have gotten if I ordered it.  Heated seats and steering wheel, and Park Assist.  Anything else would have strictly been ego-boosting, not things I needed.  In the process, I saved literally thousands of dollars and bought an SAV I could actually afford, enjoy, and be proud of.Ôªø

text: The only car feature I find annoying is gestures. Everything else I can easily find valuable, voice control so you don't have to take your hands off the wheel, or eyes with concentration of the road, bings/bongs to keep the driver more aware then just a small glowing light that can easily ignored. Bigger key fob to have more features, plus if you spend a bunch of money then I'd hope to get a large fancy fob (like that cool BMW touch screen one, over the top but cool), lack of buttons is okay as it allows you to have more features in a small screen rather then a cluttered center console, electronic e-brake is okay, yeah it can take away cool drifts but I don't think everyone drifts or whatever, start stop is normally something you can turn off in settings most of the times,  lane departure systems is something the world needs to try so later they enhance/develop a more advanced autonomous driving, and tire repair kits are fine tbh, if it fixes your tire for long enough to get you somewhere to get fixed then it's fine, plus some people just end up taking it out. Not to say that every point in this video is wrong, but I just find most of the facts in it to be completely useless to the average consumer. Still, none the less, this is good video!Ôªø

text: A feature that annoys me is the space saver spare wheel. They're an abomination and should be illegal. They're only rated to 80kph or 50mph so on a motorway you are a danger to yourself and all other drivers. Also because the tread pattern is inferior to the other three full size wheels the car doesn't handle anywhere near as well as it would when fitted with a full size spare wheel. That can create dangerous situations that could cause you to lose control, especially on wet greasy roads.Ôªø
author: Aussie Pom

text: Aussie Pom it‚Äôs only designed to get you to a place to have it fixed or repaired. The alternative would be to have the car towed or to remove the tire, have a means of bringing the tire to be repaired or replaced, then returning to the car and replacing the tire. If you had a full size spare you would still need to have the bad tire repaired.Ôªø
author: John P

text:
@John P But a full size spare is needed on our terrible roads (Australia) Space savers just don't cut it. If it's night time you can't get a full size tyre repaired as tyre places aren't open at night here anyway.
Also start/stop is a pain in the arse and I'd have the activating circuit removed by an auto electrician. 
The traditional key is far better that push button start coupled with proximity keys. The plastic push button start will break as the plastic ages.
The endless chimes when low on fuel, opening a door, or if you've left the headlights on and they're not on an auto system. Manufacturers could link the headlights to the ignition so when you turn the car off the headlights go off too. My dad's 1976VW Golf had that. But now it's endless chimes, bongs and dings.
Voice control is alright until the voice changes like if you have a cold and your voice is much deeper then the voice control doesn't recognise your voice.
Electronic handbrake is another gizmo that'll wear out long before a traditional handbrake will. Traditional handbrakes also come with a self adjusting handbrake cable.
Touch screens. We don't need apple car play or android car play. You're there to drive not fiddle with the entertainment system and no one is going to pull over to the side of the road, stop and do it.
Lane departure warnings for people who are too busy fiddling with the android and apple play or who have their face buried in a smart phone merrily texting.  
Blind spot monitoring. There is no such thing as a blind spot. It's a car manufacturer invention. If people have the exterior mirrors adjusted properly then they have no blind spot and no need for blind spot monitoring. The mirrors should be adjusted to the lane next to you not looking down the side of your car. Believe it or not the side of your car will not leave you. It will remain there for your entire journey. People say what about parking when you need to see down the side of the car. Well all cars now have electrically adjustable mirrors so people can adjust them for parking and readjust them for driving on the road.Ôªø

author: iYOLO YT

text:
So i can safely say that my start / stop system saves me a bunch of money. I personally drive a lot every day and cause im using only oil made by the manufacturer specifically for my car there should be not munch more engine wear when the oil has warmed up. Granted in siberia or russia or sth it could be a problem but my car does not activate (or let me activate) start stop until the engine got over a certain amount of temperature. in my experience the start stoop feature saves me about 5 - 15% in the rush our or any kind of start stop traffic. what im doin in traffic all the time is: looking ahead if its even worth to start up the engine again cause a couple cars ahead the cars stopped again. so from "a couple seconds" in my case its of like 20 / 30 secs per start stop cycle. btw: its easy for engineers to develop a starter that does not break. its 2018 and not 1918.

So if you guys drive a lot in traffic jams use your start stop feature. it will save you money. i drove about 10k with start stop and 10k without and it saves fuel.Ôªø

text: #9 I THINK it was about 2010 I first heard that Car makers were doing away with spare tire. They claimed weight & cost savings and that only 1 out of 100 car buyers ever needed it. Sucks to be that 1 now don't it?  Fall of 2014 I bought a used 2012 Kia Soul. To my surprise no spare tire. Just an air pump that plugs into power outlets in the car. I went to a Kia dealership & dropped $200 for a spare & the jack kit.  A year ago my mother bought a brand new Kia Soul for herself. i made the dealership throw in a spare & jack kit. Sure we might not ever need it, but it'd sure suck to sit there on the side of the road for 2 hours minimum waiting on a tow truck, & even then not being able to go where you wanted to go. Nope, off to the tire shop with you! Assuming they are open right then!Ôªø

text:
The "repair kit" for the flat tire is, for me, the worst thing ever. The other features, let's say that you can ignore them if you don't like them. (i.e. bmw handsfree features or new bmw key with the lcd screen)
But no real spare tire? Really? Imagine that you are in the middle of nowhere, late at night, you are on your way for holidays with your family (wife+children) and you've got a flat tire. If the hole is big in the tire, the "repair kit" is useless and you are stuck in a car with only 3 tires "working" and with your family in it waiting to arrive at your holiday destination. Excellent situation, ah?
And the most annuying? In most modern cars (even in some saloon or SUV cars), you can't get a spare tire anymore. Only the "repair kit". Thanks a lot the marketing guys in the automobile industries for the repair kits!!!Ôªø

text:
Reason not to love airbags? They do not improve survivability or reduce injuries over wearing a properly adjusted sealbelt.  They have killed or injured dozens of drivers and front seat passengers wearing set belts  who were NOT in accidents at the time, and inconvenienced almost a half BILLION owners in the recall/replacement process.

Not minded: lights on reminder.
Not Minded: door ajar indicator.

Unwanted: TPMS. As implemented it makes changing from summer to winter tires awkward and more expensive, leading many owners to not use winter tires when they should, and decreasing winter road safety.Ôªø

text: The spare tire was NOT removed for more trunk space, it was removed to save weight and get better fuel mileage.  That being said, ash anyone read the safety warnings on those trie repair cans?  "Do not store in trunk as temperatures may exceed 140 F and the can explode"?  And I have driven rocks through my tire twice in my life.  Those tire repair kits are great if you get a nail or screw in the tire, but are useless for a two inch hole.  ALWAYS get the spare tire, especially if you like to hike.  You are often quite a way up a logging road and it is twenty miles to walk before you get a cell signal.Ôªø

text:
The emergency hand break was an improvement over the foot parking brake pedal and release handle under the dashboard during a break failure situation which I experienced on a couple of occasions.
I've had a master cylinder failure once and a brake line blowout once and without the hydraulic brake pressure your only option is the mechanical hand emergency brake to apply the rear drums or discs.
If you are on the road and lose your hydraulic brakes pull over onto the shoulder of the roadway take your foot off the gas and press in the brake handle release button and slowly/gradually raise the brake lever to avoid spinning the vehicle out and once the vehicle has stopped apply the brake pedal to shift into park (automatic transmission) or apply the clutch and shift into neutral and shut off the engine.
Unfortunately they don't teach people how to stop using the hand brake anymore.Ôªø

text: Another aspect about keyless entry fobs is the staggering cost and complexity of replacement. We currently own both a Samsung SM7 and a Hyundai Azera and have had the wretched performance of having to replace an electronic fob on both these cars. I won't go into the sordid details of what is involved but would advise anyone who is buying any car with this type of entry key to check that you have two FULLY working sets and to keep the metal key insert separate from the fob if at all possible.You can expect great inconvenience and considerable time and expense replacing these items. (No it's not just a quick trip the dealer). If by bad luck you lose both sets or they simply stop working you are completely screwed especially if it's an automatic. That's SERIOUSLY screwed. You have been warned!Ôªø

author: Edwin Dungdung

text: As a technician, i have to clarify something for everyone who really cares. Start/Stop feature only activates if the vehicle is at operating temperature, and is not demanding defrost, a/c, or any extra electrical load. It is, for the most part, non-invasive to the driver experience, as it only does its thing when you need the engine the least. And as it goes for extra wear, that is non-existent, because like I said, the engine is going to be at operating temperature. And you don't have to worry about burning out a starter, because it uses direct injection and a spark plug to start it back up.Ôªø

author: mike Jones

text:
On an MX-5 the tyre repair kit is a pretty important feature. Boot (you're English, it's not a trunk; what are you carrying, Victorian travelling accoutrements?) space is ... adequate ... just ... for a short trip or light shopping ... with no spare wheel.

Why can't car alarms be silenced? A "yes, thanks, shut up now" button is useful.

In aviation there are many audible warnings. While some are to be responded to immediately (certain ground proximity warnings, about to land with the landing gear up etc) others are not always, and in some circumstances it is safer to leave the emergency a few minutes until the aircraft is in a safe situation (engine fire just at take-off for example; it is left until safely airborne as the design allows for a few minutes of fire without further hazard and jet engines are meant to be on fire inside anyway). In this case the pilots' first action is to silence the alarms. The big red lights, or amber lights for less serious problems, keep glowing or flashing, but the flight deck is quiet and the crew can focus.Ôªø

author: oscarnovember

text:
My 12-year old car is so wonderfully unintrusive compared to the new cars I've driven. Mine only ever beeps at me to warn me I've left the headlights on, otherwise it just quietly does its job and lets me do mine. No incessant beeping from blind spot monitoring, no annoying tugging at the wheel from *lane keep assist*. How lazy and inept do you need to be to want such a thing?

And I couldn't agree more with the electric parking brake thing. I've never even done a handbrake turn (I know, I'm boring), so it's not even about that - I just prefer the feel of the mechanical lever.Ôªø

text:
Dear Sir - I have never agreed more with anybody in my life. U are 100% SPOT ON. Electronic "features" has become a burden. I have chosen an older, little car without all the horrible "playtoy". Touch screen are among the worst things ever thrown into cars, and they cost lives. people clowning with their screen (or smartphone) instead of focusing on the driving. Driving a car can be ZEN, if U just drive. 
Touch screens of all kinds, mainly smart phones af course - are playtoy for girls. Arrow navigating is completely superior to touch screens - but they force touch screens on us.
Oh that BMW remote control there - horrible peace of shite. Not that a remote car key isn`t good, if kept small and basic, but BMW seemingly took the worst possible approach, and made it as complicated and useless as they could. I almost puked when I saw it.
I have a small, cheap, simple car, a little Opel Corsa, and I love it. Not only was it cheap second hand buy - it does everything the right way, no futuristic, suitcase size "car key" here. 
You Sir - are a genious, and I have never agreed more with anyone. BIG thumbs up from me...Ôªø

text:
None of my cars make any bongs or chimes during normal driving. Audio when I want it, bluetooth phone calls when I'm talking, that's it.
I do get chimes when I leave the lights on after stopping the car, door's open when the car is moving, or someone doesn't have a seatbelt on, but I like all of those.
So far I only have small keyless entry/keyless start fobs and I do find them convenient, though I'm a little worried about the ease of a thief reprogramming the car to accept a new fob.
The loss of a spare tire fucking blows.
Don't have any cars with big touch screens, voice control or gesture systems. All three of my cars have a ~8" touch screen and all are pretty good.
I haven't tried any cars with driver assistance features yet. I do want fully automated cars before my kids need to drive.Ôªø

text: I still like window winders sometimes.....  but seriously the "stop-start" debate is a lot more complex then the 8 other things - there is genuine fuel savings on a commute. I spend about 50% of my time stationary at lights and this could be a saving on approx 1 litre per hour (for my engine), engine wear can be reduced by the use of new bearing materials and oils, there is also a serious reduction in pollution if you consider a traffic jam of switched off engines. Some systems will not switch off when cold, low battery, or a number of other conditions - but I know people who were really fuel concious and would coast to a standstill with the engine already off (I know, dangerous no power steering or brake servo) and only start when the lights went green - but the debate over stop-start is more complex then presented here....Ôªø

author: Joshua Nicolai

text:
The 9 most annoying features were that none of the 9 in here were actually annoying and all described by someone who appears to know nothing about cars and is perhaps still living in the 1950s!

1. I don't get a bong that reminds me to put my seatbelt on. I do that as a matter of course. A bong that tells me I have lost brake pressure before I next glance a the dash, or that warns me there is a big problem, look at the lights now, very useful

2. Not annoying at all, and for the generations who are growing up with Cortana and Siri, perfectly natural. I don't know of any vehicle where it is the sole method of control. Only annoying if you use it and it doesnt work, dont use it and it cant annoy. How simple a concept is that?

3. See 2. 

4. Does save fuel. Makes living next to a busy junction quieter. 

5. Seriously, how many people actually use the parking brake for anything other than parking? Heck lots of people with autos dont even use it for that. A little button, even better the automatic one that is available on many new vehicles, with added benefits such as anti-roll-back for starting on slopes, far more sensible. Nobody I know uses it "on the track" either, just sometimes very rarely on very certain kinds of track, such as in rallying as you show. You do not need the handbrake to perform powerslides or drifts either

6 Keyless entry. So I can have a little card or fob (smaller than most smartphones) anywhere on my person and just jump in and go. No digging keys out of pockets or bags, no finding the right key on the ring, no sharp edges shredding my pocket linings. You really did get that one backwards.

7 Of course, nobody ever hit the wrong radio station button before touchscreens. Drivers are not "forced to browse around", all the regular, important features are still good old stalks etc, even on that nice new shiny Tesla. Other than tactile feedback, just how is a button on a touchscreen any different from a mechanical button? Especially as mechanical buttons havent actually switched much on or off for many years, merely told a computer to do it. 

8 LDS. Ever driven with it? they do not "rebound" or insist, they are easily overridden with minimum pressure on the wheel

9 I haven't had a puncture on a paved road in years, and a can of sealant is quicker and safer for the average Joe than trying a wheelchange at the roadside, especially on fast roads.Ôªø

The electric handbrake did not work and the powered brake did not work, all of them required a started engine. I was so glad that there was no car behind me and I was at the beginning of that slope. author: Seth King

text:
1:  I would leave my sunroof open all the time without an audible reminder.
4:  Starting doesn‚Äôt wear down your engine.  It only wears down your starter motor, and starter motors in start/stop vehicles are more robust.
6:  There is only a finite number of key possibilities on a physical key, because you can only fit a finite number of tumblers in the lock.  In the 80s, my dad once got in the wrong car in a store parking lot, and drove it halfway home before he realized it wasn‚Äôt his car.  Electronic keys allow every key (not just every car) to have a completely unique identification code.
8:  I‚Äôve never been in a lane assist vehicle that kept a vehicle in the center of the lane.  It just kept them from crossing over the line.

4 features I DO want.Ôªø

text:
I did like many of the features, on this list. text: Remote start is handy but my father finally bought a new car and let me tell you: It confuses him. His last new car was a '86 Cordoba and after that, he drove seventh generation Thunderbirds with his last being a '79 Heritage up until 2010. Well, he bought a 2017 Cherokee Sport Altitude in July and likes it, but coming back from the dealership the stop/start feature spooked him. He thought his brand new ride stalled on him or broke. He read the entire manual and knows how all the physical buttons work and what they do now, but he can't figure out the touchscreen. Additionally, I had to show him how to turn the headlights on and use the wipers, because you know, those old boats that I love had knobs on the dashboard for that when they're on the stocks now. author: Shotgun93Alexander

text:
Number 4: It actually uses MORE fuel. That fuel you "save" by turning the engine off for a few seconds is quickly spent when you crank it and get it started up all over again. The alternator drains the battery of a bunch of electricity which the car has to replace by acting like a generator, and it costs a small burst of gasoline to get the engine "flamed up" again especially in cold weather, vs maintaining Low RPM idle. You get this "Low RPM->Nothing->High RPM burst->Low RPM" instead of just Low RPM the whole time.

Also, it's kind of like turning an incandescent light bulb on and off several times in quick succession.Ôªø
author: Dhalin

text: Not to mention extra engine wear.¬† When you first start an engine,¬†that's when most wear occurs.¬† ¬†This takes years to amount to anything but with start/stop, you greatly increase the amount of cycles.Ôªø

text:
Any kind of touch screen in a car is dangerous. I would rather a dashboard with 100 different switches and controls that have a simple on/off function than have to navigate through multiple menus on a touch screen while trying to drive.
These things are designed by university educated star trek watching geeks hardly old enough to drive. Touch screens look cool in their favourite sci-fi movie and work great sitting still in a room in the development department but out in the real world they are a anathema.

When driving you need simple controls. One switch controls one function on or off. No thinking involved, no searching around involved, you can operate the control without looking and without making any decisions.Ôªø

author: Harshith Velicheti

text:
I agree with all of these. Can I include the "Tokyo by night" look of modern dashboards? When I learnt to drive, the inside of a car was dark at night, no lights at all, except the soft glow of the speedo dial, you wanted a switch? you felt for it and bloody remembered where it was. Now everything lights up, little distracting lights all over the shop.

And dashboards my first car had a plank of wood, no really.  Below that was nothing, no centre console, no bulky heater (that was under the bonnet/hood), actually no transmission hump as it was FWD. There was just space, there was nothing between your feet and the passenger's feet. Passenger airbag? no need the dash was so far away that you were never going to hit it anyway.

But now dashboards have grown and grown, the space to move about a wriggle has gone, Stuff something between the seats? no room, all centre console and switches and more switches and little light and things you never use.

What do you need a dashboard for anyway? Get rid of it entirely, give me a speedo in front of the wheel, maybe a tacho and a satnav/radio who needs anything else?  All would fit in a little binnacle by the driver, all the rest, space.

Oh and blue LEDs they are not cool any more, never were really.Ôªø

text:
Anything that makes the car "smarter than the user" and can't be easily (and permanently) turned off is a pain in the a**. I once drove a car that wouldn't go if the tunk wasn't closed. I know it generally a good idea to drive with the trunk closed, but sometimes I do tend to carry oversized stuff over short distances. Sometimes even not on public roads. So if my car had a system that prevented that, I'd be seriously pissed off. 
Acutally, the more automated cars get, the more I dream of having an "entirely analog" old car with no electronics whatsoever (maybe except for the radio :P). On the other hand, ABS saved my a** a couple of times so it's a not an easy choiceÔªø

text: nddd nss, a basic key can easily be built with an RFID type sensor that keeps the doors from locking if inside the car. Besides, the keyless fobs add another problem: if the car has a stick, you can't bump start it because there's no way to switch on the ignition on certain brands such as VW. I do have voice control, which I never need to use, and if I opted for a spare tyre it would have been a full-size one hanging under the boot floor (but I have an LPG tank hanging in its place).Ôªø

author: Alex Tepozteco

text:
What annoys me are 3 things.
1. Keyless ignition. Slightly more convenient than keyed ignition, cost a fortune to repair.
2. Electronic throttles. All that can do is increase or decrease throttle response rate, which is stupid. If I want to drive fast, I'll slam it down. If I want to go slow, I'll be gentle with it. Why would anyone need a computer to change their driving speed?
3. Electronic steering. It's like having a thick layer of fat under your shoe while you run. All that does is filter out all the bumps and difference in traction on the road from your hands and arms.Ôªø

text:
I got a car 2 years ago with keyless entry and gave my older car to my other half. 
Every time, EVERY TIME I go to drive her car, I stand there, yanking on the door handle with the keys clipped to my beltloop expecting it to open before I realize "Duh, keys." Then I get in and try to push the button on the dash to turn the car on. The button that doesn't exist, because "DUH, KEYS! YOU JUST DID THIS 2 SECONDS AGO WITH THE DOOR LOCK!" 

Every time. It never fails. I hate keys so much now. 
My least favorite feature on my car is an auto dimming mirror I can't turn off. I've never been blinded by a car in my rear-view. But when it's dark, I can't see a thing out the back.Ôªø

author: Bennet brauer Reporting from a van by the river

text:
Ah, so glad I don't have a Hyundai and their weird sounds, but the voice control on my family Corolla though.... 

I admit, some of the sounds are needed to idiot proof  "drivers" (which California has an ample supply of) 

What's worse with start-stop is that if you shift into neutral, start stop didn't work.... WHY?! There are lots of terrible roads here with inconsistent or missing markers or possibly mismatched with the pavement groove. I would love to test lane departure on those roads. 

I don't like the electronic brake, but I'll take it over the footbrake. I don't know where you're from, but tyre fill kits do not give more space in the trunk, at least in my experience. 

So that's what BMW has become, eh? I guess I'll stick with the E39 then... 

Is "styling" a feature? Because "styling" had left visibility in the dust. I don't understand new car styling but I do know they create a lot of blind spots. 

No mention of the V6's replacement by the unreliable and crude Turbo-4? What are you, a Brit?Ôªø

author: Federico Bertagna

text: I know this comment is 5 months old, but I'm going to answer this anyways. It's more fun. That simple. Driving a manual gives you a feeling of being one with the car. Automatics require no outside interference other than turning the steering wheel and applying the brakes and gas when needed. It gets monotonous after a while. A manual on the other hand demands your attention almost all the time, requiring input from most of your limbs. Left foot, clutch in. Right hand, downshift. Right foot, rev your engine. Left foot, off clutch. It's poetic almost. This is also coming from a guy who doesn't know a lot about cars and taught himself how to drive manual. So, take this with a grain of salt.Ôªø
author: Samuel Agan

text: From Europe, bought a new manual last year (custom order to the factory in France). The data on automatic was 1L per 100km more than comparable manual. I'm not the most conservative drive and I do about 5-5,2L per 100km - Google tells me this is 46 mpgÔªø

author: Rehaan Hussain

text: I agree with pretty much everything you said there. My mate owns a Mk7 Golf, has the touch screen option fitted, and Jesus Christ do I hate it. I genuinely think touch screens are so dangerous in cars, far too distracting. Unlike a button you lose one of your senses, you can't operate the cars functions by touch. Which means you have to do it by sight, you need to physically look at where you're  pressing to make sure your doing it. And usually you need to keep looking to check your input was recognised cos half the touch screens crash or go unresponsive randomly. And if you're  on a bumpy road it's a fucking nightmare to change the radio station, your hand getting thrown all over the screen, and you end up adjusting the weight of the steering instead of changing the radio. I own a Porsche 944, it has a rear wiper and a heated rear window and a cassette player. That's it. And I can find all of those buttons by touch without looking away from the road. Meanwhile my mate in his Golf is fiddling with the suspension settings and fucking about with how long he wants the kerb lights on when he turns the ignition off, why??? Why does his car need to do this? Why are modern cars filled with all this useless shit we don't need? How come we have to buy a car and then spend forever adjusting it? Why can't we just have a car that moves us around and is set up the best way to begin with.... like mine isÔªø

text: Not only do start/stop buttons defeat their own purpose, but because the button can easily start up the car, thieves can just simply smash the driver window, open the door, get in, press the start/stop button, and simply drive off, assuming you own an automatic transmission. text: I couldn't agree more with this video. I have one great example for the voice control: My father drives a 2017 BMW 520d, which is said to have the best voice control system in the world at the moment. He wanted to call my grandma (his mother) and so he said to his car "call Mum". The car replied with " 'Mother' can not be found in your contacts". And this drove my Dad mad - because the car understood that he wanted to call his mother, but wasn't able to just select the contact that was named "Mum" which was just what he said. "Mother" was indeed not a contact, but that's not what my Dad had asked for anyways. Anyways, after a bit of arguing with the car, it decided to solve the Problem once and for all - the conversation ended with the car's hilarious message: " 'Mum' has been added to your Mother" üòÇÔªø

text: I'm an old schooler who believes the older cars were better. One day I was getting off the highway and saw a man standing next to his BMW with the hood up. I asked what was wrong & he said he was low on oil. I always carry some in my truck & offered to help. He said he's not sure how much he needed so I told him to check the dip stick. That's when he told me the new BMWs don't have them anymore they go by their onboard computers now. What happens when the computer decides not to work anymore? text: 1. The warning sounds:when your seatbelt is not fastened and your just going to do repark your car in a parking lot, tell me, would you fasten your seatbelt because of a light in the dashboard? No! And parking lots are VERY unsafe, because due to parked cars, you may not see a car turning at a turn for example, and they would smash into you 2. Here you say you should rather do it yourself, but later in the video you say touching screens while driving is unsafe. Pick one! 3. Okay you won this one. But you have to admit its pretty cool. 4. I'd DOES save fuel, fifth gear once proved it, and of you don't like it you can just turn it off.5. the electronic handbrake not only makes cars interiors much prettier, but it's also a safety feature. When the driver faints or has a heart attack, the passenger can pull it to stop the car relatively safely, unlike with regular handbrakes.6. while huge keyfobs aren't good, the bmw screen-key you showed can be genuinely useful for example like you showed there, you can check the cars fluids without even getting in the car which is good for non car people. 7. Touchscreens are also for cleaning up interiors but they also help the elderly or ppl with bad vision because there can be just some of the buttons on different screens making them larger instead of putting a million tiny buttons all over the place.8. the sverving thing would never happen because the systems aren't stupid. They just make you safer, like if you fainted or fell asleep behind the wheel, you would thank the system for not crashing into a pole and taking turns or maybe stopping and putting the hazards on.9. in my opinion, it is worth it, because it works and most people would throw the old tyre out anyway. I get that all of these things have disadvantages, but their advantages (in my opinion) outweigh themÔªø

author: White Darkness

text:
SEATBELT WARNING (and al the other beepy stuff)...SUCK!!
I didn't even know something like hand gesture control exists lol. And the E-handbrake is in my opinion good. If you do nothing but daily driving with your car. But if it can get annoying. For example, my dad owns a 2008 Renault Espace and sometimes for literally no reason it says that the handbrake is broken. Even tho it works just fine. At the end, he has to go to a service where they deactivate this warning trough computer (by the way it isn't quite cheap what gets me the most. Also, you have to rev the car up to like 5000 RPM which in diesel...you get the idea. But there is always the option to install a hydraulic handbrake since if you use the normal handbrake too much it will damage or even break down completely. With the keys: They are useful, with the feature that if you need to open the boot of your car you just press a button. Or if your child wants to get to the car as quickly as possible you can open it from distance. But I think there is no better feeling than turning that key and seeing the engine startup (or not if you have a project car) apart from well-executed handbrake turn obviously. And I think that the 'normal' keys washed off because of people got lazier and also, let's be honest the locks were quite easy to break in. Touchscreen commands are however a very good feature if the screen's placed in good position. It in many cases allows getting more sophisticated and faster system into the computer. Unlike buttons, there is usually quite short or no delay at all between the moment you press the screen and computer's reaction. Of course, it has some flaws. You mentioned the main ones: precision and safety. In that case, I think the driver should be allowed to use the touchscreen or ordinary buttons. Becuase it isn't a bad idea to just play with the touchscreen while you're waiting somewhere but when you're moving it all different game. So...chaning lanes with the computer. Unless we have perfect top-notch roads all over the world, these systems are useless, for example here in the Czech Republic (or Czechia if you will) the roads especially the main roads or even highways are so bad that the Tesla system wouldn't even allow you to turn it on. Also, I think that all the systems are made for these top-notch roads and therefore they may make a mistake if you drive somewhere, where it isn't the top-notch quality. But I have to admit that sign reading systems are useful unless it limits your top speed at what the sign says.Ôªø
author: Eli√°≈° Mach√°lek

text:
The first point is the one with which I disagree the most. There are tons of unnecessary sounds some cars make, but a couple should definitely be there. If a seat belt warning doesn't make noise, a lot more people will just ignore it. Obviously, just putting on a dash light would be completely useless for leaving keys in the car.
There were a couple other points that maybe YOU don't like, but plenty of other people would enjoy (if they even care). I only use my parking brake for parking on a hill, and I can't think of a time I'd be annoyed by engine stop/start.
I agree completely about the spare tire. It is absolutely not worth the sacrifice for just a bit more cargo room.Ôªø

text:
After driving my 74 datsun, "modern" cars feel like driving a whiny Ipad instead of a car due to all the bongs, beeps, warnings, driver assists. Just learn how to drive, stay in your lane, adjust your speed when the person in front of you slows down/speeds up and parallel park your own car.
